page.title: 01Costessey
page.content:
Costessey is an Anglo-Saxon placename, coming from Cost's Ey, which means Cost's Island. It grew up on a piece of land next to the River Wensum surrounded by marshy ground, so no doubt it was an island, or nearly one, in those days.
On the North side of the river is the parish of Hellesdon, where Edmund, King of the East Angles, was martyred, so it is not surprising that the village church in Costessey is dedicated to Saint Edmund.
The unusual thing about the name 'Costessey' is that it is pronounced 'Cossey' by local people, which confuses 'foreigners'.
